title: Miles Jupp webchat â your questions answered on comedy, class and Balamory | Stage | The Guardian

documents.title: time 's up
text: guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 2:15pm thanks very much for your questions .
i think it 's good that people throw in the odd snarky one - it makes it a bit more like real conversation !
i 'm sorry that i 'm not doctor who or someone , but you know , there we are .
back to work everybody !
gretsch83 asks : you 're a fellow edinburgh university alumnus of gordon brown , pippa middleton and julius nyerere .
out of these three , who would you say you are most similar to and why ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 2:14pm i 've always thought of myself of a cross between gordon brown and pippa middleton , for reasons that are , i hope , extremely obvious .
id6440291 asks : what was the programme you were recording near teddington lock about three years ago ?
did it ever see the light of day ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 2:12pm it was the television version of in and out of the kitchen , which saw a very thin glimmer of daylight .
filming at teddington lock was interrupted by a man who took his top off and wanted to jump off a bridge , but was talked down by the first ad , who was a former military policeman .
extraordinary scenes .

documents.title: class
text: shakercoola asks : do you think class is something one ought to discover about another rather than it being imposed through self-reference in the hope to elicit the estimation in which one should be held by others ?
to which risennorth adds : parklife !
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 2:11pm yes .
the estimation in which you 're held by others should be unaffected by class , should n't it ?
but perhaps self-deprecating remarks that people make about their own class are in fact just as much a part of the problem as anything else .
really good question .
unstoppablesteve asks : with regards to the news quiz , have there been any orders from above to take it easy on the tories ?
it 's been noticeable that the government gets a fairly easy ride compared to previous series , especially when jeremy hardy 's not on the panel .
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 2:08pm absolutely no way have there been orders to take it easy on the tories .
we 're only two episodes in , so who knows what might happen .
from the point of view of writing and performing on the show , pretty much anyone is fair game .
but certainly jeremy , as you suggest , is more likely to aim his ire to the right than the left .
and very funny he is doing it too .
id8378794 writes : with the current politics in the uk and us , it must be a strange time for comedians as the reality seems a little surreal .
has this situation made it more or less difficult for comedians ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 2:06pm it 's made it easier in the sense that there is more to talk about .
but harder to assume an aloof position from which you can reflect on the whole spectrum , because it 's so obvious who the villains and the failures are .

documents.title: thumbs-up for stafford
text: jennifer woodyard asks : what did you think of the town of stafford when you visited last week ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 2:03pm that was my fourth visit to stafford in recent years .
and my favourite yet !
what a great bunch of people .
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 2:03pm there was a pizza express near the station , and my tour manager had vouchers .
very little to complain about on the stafford front .
lammypie asks : why do i love you ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 2:04pm i 'm not sure that you do .
you just think that you do .
probably because you do n't know what i 'm really like .
aslater23 says : you always seem to genuinely laugh a lot with other guests when appearing on panel shows .
which of these shows do you most enjoy appearing on and which comedians do you find the funniest in this format ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 2:00pm i really like being on would i lie to you ?
and have i got news for you .

i think the person who has made me laugh the most on a panel show was joe wilkinson , who interrupted a needlessly unpleasant and filthy exchange on something with the words : `` i ca n't believe i missed zumba for this . ''
lewis coates asks : when you 're tucking into a nice bit of rabbit , does it make you think of watership down ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 2:02pm i remember once being on holiday with my parents in a restaurant in france , and pleading with my father not to eat rabbit .
because rabbits were animals .
he said : what are you going to have ?
i said : chicken .
wicksey asks : if you were best friends with your brother as a kid how would you get in touch ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:58pm do you mean if i were , or you were ?
i can ring him , but this sounds to me like the sort of thing the internet could help with .

documents.title: wollongong shock
text: mrshoppo1 asks : as you were in a food-related comedy on radio 4 , i would like to know what is the worst meal you have ever been served in a restaurant ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:57pm i ca n't remember the name of the restaurant or even what i ordered , but it was in wollongong in australia .
it was so appalling that it made me wonder how the human race had ever achieved anything .
donkeylogic asks : when do you think we can get someone else to host the news quiz ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:55pm great idea , let 's ask around i wo n't do it as long as sandi , but will probably do it for longer than barry norman .
fieryjackass says : doing a fabulous job on the news quiz , i think .
- dream guest line-up ? - would be good if news quiz extra was an hour long , even if that softens the laughs-per-minute .
been to quite a few tapings and a lot of gold ends up on the floor .
any chance ? - can you inform susan calman that scottish bank notes are not legal tender ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:54pm - michael atherton .
isabelle huppert .
david hyde pierce .
and a competition winner .
- i would love it if it was an hour , yeah .
quite often we record for an hour and three quarters , so it ought not to be too much of a struggle .
it would also be , and this is not a good reason for anything , cheap .
- only if i was in a mood to antagonise .
i mean , they are .
why do you want me to be part of your perverted conspiracy ?
sharmadelica writes : i loved your book fibber in the heat .
as with homer buying marge a bowling ball , i bought it for my dad but kept it for myself .

given that you thought you could turn your hand to cricket journalism , which would have been your dream job , is there now a new dream job that has replaced it , and could you please write a book about your attempts to fulfil this unreachable destiny ?
ps : i saw you do stand-up in aberdeen many years ago .
do n't remember anything about anyone else on the bill , but you were terrific .
i have stolen your getting abuse for being posh , so i instructed my servants to carry my sedan chair away as quickly as possible joke on a few occasions .
it went down well .
thanks for making me funny by proxy .
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:51pm would you read a book about my attempts to become a bounty hunter ?
that is a context which ought to throw up a few `` in at the deep end '' moments .
in fact it would be so fish-out-of-water it would be nauseating .
oneforthetreble asks : do you think the c of e is heading for a split ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:49pm could be .
i think they 're unlikely to formalise the current informal split , but that said , i do n't really know anything about it .
perfumedponce wonders : would you consider a project i am working on which is part balamory , part wicker man ?
john o'donnell says : this must be made !
and markear adds : i hereby offer my services as the stunt double for britt eckland 's arse in this upcoming project .
i know how to shake one 's booty as the youth say .
miles : are you in or what ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:44pm it depends which bits of each story you intended to appropriate .
the dancing scenes in the wicker man are , i would have thought , preferable to those in balamory .
in fact , there is an actor that was in balamory and the wicker man , but you will of course already know this as part of your background research juliet cadzow .

you 've got to consider if you going to go the edward woodward or pc plum route for your policeman character , but you may feel capable of making a policeman character that contains the best of both of them .
but look , clearly this idea has legs , and if it does n't happen then i think there are worrying implications for the future of the british film industry .
abitofblue asks : which relation of yours pulled some strings ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:48pm they all have , in a way .
if your father 's a clergyman , and your mother 's a conveyancing solicitor , and your brother 's a librarian , then everything just gets handed to you , does n't it ?

one of my children are already in the running to become the next director general of the bbc , and another to become the editor of the guardian , even though i 've told both of them in no uncertain terms that each is a poisoned chalice .

documents.title: manners
text: davidabsalom asks : where did you get such perfect manners from ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:46pm from the absolute shame i feel whenever i inconvenience other people .
some of it 's just good sense , is n't it ?
but of course , the other thing , is that manners are a really good way of concealing what you 're really thinking .
ditchdog says : hi miles , i love in and out of the kitchen , are there plans for any more ?
i also loved the cricket book too .
id8952982 adds : more damien trench please !
and recipes lots of recipes .
and dillydaydream78 agrees : this !
i 'm desperately hoping there 'll be a fifth radio series - in and out of the kitchen is one of the best radio comedies i 've ever heard .
more please !
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:40pm there are no plans for further radio series , but i do have a number of other plans for damien and the other characters .
i 'm currently writing damien 's childhood memoir , which will be out next year .
mmmbisto asks : is your wife editor of panorama ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:38pm she is not .
nor , and i say this respectfully , is she qualified to be .
extremophilesheep says : can you please slow down a bit ?
i love news quiz and really like your quips , esp the ones after each subject , but not being a native speaker i keep having to rewind to find out what was being said .
thank you very much .
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:35pm i .
will .
try .
dwfan1 asks : what 's your favourite pixar film ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:37pm toy story - i just think it 's the coolest and the sweetest and the funniest .
that said , i do love monsters inc - i would n't have nothing if i did n't have you is an amazing song .
but i love all the ones where randy newman wrote the music .
warspite1944 adds : do you keep in touch with miss hoolie ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:34pm yeah , i keep in touch with loads of them .

documents.title: second balamory question
text: puncrock asks : is it true that miss hoolie now works at donald trump 's golf course as head of corporate intelligence ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:34pm it is true .
and looking back , it was always going to be the case .
the balamory crew ¦ including miles jupp as archie , second from left , and julie wilson nimmo as ms hoolie , centre in red gloves .
scotland
luigilovelobes asks : i 'm a keen cyclist should i deodorise my bottom ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:32pm yes , why not ?
perhaps while you 're waiting at traffic lights .
stikinsekt asks : how did things come to this ?
and why does it matter ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:32pm well , quite .
images/dorling kindersley oathkeeper says : miles , you were joseph ' to my sister 's mary ' in the nativity at st andrews church circa 1986 .
how much do you think we can make trading on that anecdote ?
do you want in ?
we have n't made a bean yet .
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:31pm it seems hard to imagine how an anecdote like that could be monetised .
although i probably got the part because my dad was minister of that church , so perhaps it 's yet another example of widescale corruption that occurs when people insist on staging nativity plays .
i 've got no recollection of this happening - i ca n't in all honesty remember it .
but i 'd be amazed if it did n't .
as to whether you keep the money , that 's for you and your conscience to decide .
hypothetically .
glen pierce wonders : are you related to musician mickey jupp ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:31pm of southend big band fame ?
i hope so !
uhurasmazda asks do you worry when panelists and audience members on the news quiz show more engagement and emotion over bake off than over the political bits in the top half of the programme ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:28pm i do , to be honest .
and more worryingly i think it reflects the population at large .
i just could n't believe what a big news story that was .
the news quiz is a classic internet-age palaver .
in the old days , people would have thought : should i care so passionately about this ?
whereas now they 're surrounded by people saying : yeah , of course you should .

documents.title: jupp the writer
text: paulmaidment asks : how much of the wonderful fibber in the heat was really true ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:25pm i changed a few names and for structural reasons changed the order of events very slightly .
mainly regarding my mood to be honest .
but yeah , that 's what happened .

there 's a bit near the end of the book , where a year after i got back from india i met a guy who , while i 'd been out there , was arrested for sitting in the press box and gambling , a man who should n't have been there .
that is the thing that happened that people seem most reluctant to believe .
david1947 asks : is it true that you are to star in the remake of the archie andrews show , and that you are to play both parts ?
awesome if the rumours are true !
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:20pm i am .
i 'm going to play all parts , write it , film it , score the music , provide the sound effects , and fund it .
it is , in a way , a vanity project .
unclearleo asks : when is the news quiz moving to talk sport ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:22pm when we 're confident enough that we 'd actually be able to sell any advertising .
hardric asks : rank the following in order of poshness : you , alexander armstrong , jack whitehall , miranda hart , john cleese .
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:21pm i would suspect it 's armstrong , whitehall , hart , jupp , cleese , from poshest to least posh .
armstrong is related to william the conqueror or something .
bobajoba asks : are you a member of the conservative party ?
if so , why ?
if not , why not ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:19pm i am not a member of the conservative party , nor have i ever thought of joining the conservative party .
what do people who join the conservative party even get ?
a tie and some complimentary online abuse , i 'd have thought .
attentionseeker asks : what is the capital of mozambique ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:17pm maputo .

documents.title: school homework corner
text: arthurgrimsdyke asks : what is your favourite bread ?
i like sainsbury 's wholemeal country loaf at the moment but i 'm thinking of trying their well fired loaf .
thoughts ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:16pm i 'm not all that confident that any of the breads from sainsbury 's taste so different from each other as to actually be noticeable .
almost all of my wife 's family are excellent bakers - it 's like something out of a g2 supplement - and the bread that they make is probably my favourite .
jon chanter asks : jupp ?
interesting name are you one of the sussex jupps ?

( or some such similar question that has been put to you a thousand times by someone with a similar accent to yours ( and mine ) and stockwellian adds : i was going to ask something very similar ( being a jupp myself ) .
we tend to be from the sussex/east surrey area originally .
although there are a bunch up in norfolk too , poor little blighters .
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:15pm i am , it turns out .
but i did n't realise for a long time .
i was under the impression for many years that it was a belgian name - in fact i was reconciled to it .
antmanbee2 asks : why did it take you so long to realise the jolly good bunch of lads punchline was tedious ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:13pm i 'm sorry you found it so tedious that you ca n't remember the correct wording of it .
that said , i struggle to remember the name of the show that was on .
fair question though !
it can be tricky , running jokes - i 'm not really sure about them .
lots of people did like it , but not finding a joke funny is definitely a valid response .
if it was tedious , it passed me by , because i have never heard an episode of the programme in question .
monkeynots asks : would you consider a john duggan sitcom series ?
as characters on different planets go , that was up there with the funniest .
in my ever so humble guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:08pm i would consider it extremely briefly and then say yes .
i 'm not sure of all the many options that armando and his cohorts have , that it is the most likely one that they would plump for .
what i loved about john duggan was that he was not only an idiot , but he was an idiot on the front foot , not some reactive ditherer .
richlieu wonders : did steve evets ever take you and the rest of the rev cast down st bernadette 's social club for a cheeky vimto or two ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:07pm sadly not .
but i did do a reasonable amount of socialising with him in the rev days , and it 's fair to say that his life has been considerably more interesting than mine .
i remember him once telling some anecdotes about the merchant navy , and simon mcburney and i looking at each other as if to say : we have not lived .
risennorth says : the news quiz is a thinly disguised party political broadcast for the labour party .
discuss .
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:05pm i 'm not sure what efforts you think are being made to disguise the fact .
how do you feel about the guardian ?
rusbirdger asks : irritatedly , what 's with the ostentatious adverbs ?
actually , i think you 've really brought the right thing to the news quiz , but i do wonder whether this particular quirk returns its investment .
your native wit carries things perfectly well .
you were great in rev too !
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:04pm they 're not only ostentatious , they are by and large completely irrelevant .
it 's simply a way of not starting the end of question roundup with the words : `` yes , this is the story `` as featured on all other panel shows about news .
sorry it irritates you .
perhaps you 're easily irritable ?
it is only silliness .
glad you liked rev , it was an amazing thing to be a part of , as they say in actor-speak .
it was an incredible bunch of people .
dweezle says : please tell us about your struggle from your bland , middle-class roots to your current position as a bland , middle-class entertainer .
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 12:58pm some of the admin has been a bit tedious , but i hope that it 's been even easier than you imagine .
some of the admin has been tedious ' ¦ miles jupp is with us in the guardian office now , answering your questions .
beaumont-thomas
liam quane asks : as an actor , what is the best thing a director can do for you on set ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 12:57pm i do sometimes like to be asked what i think .
and then when i do n't know what to think , be able to ask them what i should think .
and continues : what was it like working on sherlock holmes ?
guy ritchie ?
robert downey jr ?
i seen you in the background lol .
: ~ ) guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 1:01pm it was one day - all i was doing was playing a waiter , with one line : `` the gentleman has already ordered for the table , sir . ''
it was , as the editors judged , completely extraneous .
the atmosphere was genuinely intimidating , and lots of people seemed utterly terrified of some of the people present .
probably with reason .
i would not have liked to have been on set three days later , when guy ritchie and madonna 's divorce was made public .
at the same time , it was really fun !
papersdeadboy asks what 's your favourite dusty springfield song ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 12:58pm i just do n't know what to do with myself .
craig hill and i once did some writing together and briefly considered doing a character for him called rusty springfield , which was basically dusty springfield who had n't done a gig for a while .

documents.title: first mention of balamory
text: djw300 also asks : do you think balamory might have been the high watermark of your career ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 12:56pm it might have been
djw300 asks : roll and sausage : do you have brown sauce red sauce or no sauce at all ?
guardian contributor milesjupp 21 september 2016 12:55pm red sauce .
if by red you mean ketchup .

documents.title: post your questions for miles jupp
text: with his sensible jumpers and waspish observations , it 's no surprise to find miles jupp as the new host of radio 4 perennial the news quiz , and raging against jam-jar cocktails in his latest stand-up show songs of freedom .
such mild-mannered irritation at modern life made jupp perfect for the role of the perpetually unimpressed lay reader nigel in bbc sitcom rev .
but he 's proved his acting chops extend far wider than this persona in a screen career that takes in everything from the legend of tarzan and the monuments men to romcom chicklit .
with songs of freedom touring the uk this autumn , miles is joining us to answer your questions in a live webchat , from 1pm bst on wednesday 21 september .
post them in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The comedian, actor and News Quiz host discussed bias at the BBC, his well-loved children's television show, and the geography of Mozambique.
